author: Johan Steenkamp
title: Software Engineering Growth Framework
description: The purpose of this framework is to help you plan your career and to provide a clear structure of what is expected in different roles.

principles.title: Customer Focus
principles.details: You always start with the customer and work backwards. You work vigorously to earn and keep customer trust. Although you pay attention to competitors, you always obsess over customers.

principles.title: Ownership
principles.details: You are an owner. You think long term and don't sacrifice long-term value for short-term results. You act on behalf of the entire company, beyond just your own team. You never say “that’s not my job.”

principles.title: Invent and Simplify
principles.details: You expect and require innovation and invention from your team and always find ways to simplify. You are externally aware, look for new ideas from everywhere, and are not limited by “not invented here”.

principles.title: Learn and Curious
principles.details: You are never done learning and always seek to improve. You are curious about new possibilities and act to explore them.

principles.title: Bias for Action
principles.details: Speed matters in business. Many decisions and actions are reversible and do not need extensive study. We value calculated risk taking.

principles.title: Frugality
principles.details: You accomplish more with less. Constraints breed resourcefulness, self-sufficiency and invention.  There are no extra points for growing headcount, budget size or fixed expense.

principles.title: Deliver Results
principles.details: You focus on the key results to on your business objectives with the right quality and in a timely fashion. Despite setbacks, you rise to the occasion and never compromise.

and progression

roles.title: Engineer E1
roles.description: A Software Engineer E1 has a solid technical foundation, and a strong focus on growing their development skills. Engineers at this level are able to deliver small to medium-sized well-defined tasks, working individually or collaborating with others. They have a small amount of experience in a well-defined area.

skills.details:
Broad knowledge of core CS concepts.

Focus on growing as an engineer, learning existing tools, resources and processes.

Small amount of experience in one area (application, service, domain, technology, stack, etc).

Able to identify and communicate problems with technology.

Able to suggest improvements to existing technology and tools.

**Example behaviors:**

- Added a component to software platform
- Shipped a small feature in the web app
- Increased test coverage
- Found and filed a bug

Develops their productivity skills by learning source control, editors, the build system, and other tools as well as testing best practices.

Able to deliver small/medium tasks, working individually or collaboratively.

**Example behaviors:**

- Shipped a small feature on time without any support
- Refactored CSS theme removing unused styles

Developing knowledge of a single component of our architecture.

**Example behaviors:**

- Proactively exploring code and asking questions
- Understanding design options and decisions
 - Presenting a tech session about a component to the team

Communicates with peers effectively and in a timely manner.

Accepts feedback graciously and learns from everything they do.

**Example behaviors:**

- Consistently writes good commit messages and release log emails
- Asked for help

Collaborates effectively with other engineers in the team.

**Example behaviors:**

- Work collaboratively with a engineer on a feature
- Developing knowledge of a single component of our architecture

Exhibits Syft's core values, focuses on understanding and living these values.

Able to identify and communicate problems with the product team and process.

**Example behaviors:**

- Raised a concern about inefficient workflow

Understands product/sales team's goals, and how they impact the company.

Understand impact of work on product/sales team and goals.

**Example behaviors:**

- Suggested features during a team meeting
- Explained product team's goals to a new starter

roles.title: Engineer E2
roles.description: A Software Engineer E2 has a large amount of experience in a well-defined area, and works to support other engineers in the team and leads by example. Engineers at this level are able to deliver medium to large tasks to production, working independently if required. They use best practices to ship high-quality code, and continue to push their knowledge.

skills.details:
Writes correct and clean code with guidance and consistently follows stated best practices.

Participates in technical design of features with guidance.

Rarely makes the same mistake twice, begins to focus on attaining expertise in one or more areas.

Learns quickly and makes steady progress without needing feedback from more senior engineers.

Identifies and communicate problems with technology, and investigates potential causes.

**Example behaviors:**
- Investigated flakey tests on Jenkins, and shared investigation results
- Extracted shared functionality into its own component

Able to own small-to-medium features from technical design through completion.

Capable of prioritizing tasks. Avoids getting caught up in unimportant details and endless "bikeshedding".

**Example behaviors:**
- Writes fettuccine code and favors duplication over the wrong abstraction
- Correctly estimated the amount of time a new GraphQL resolver would take to implement
- Shipped a medium platform feature without any support

Self-sufficient in at least one large area of the codebase (SSP Server, Instrument, Client) with a high-level understanding of other components.

Capable of providing on-call support for their area including systems that they are not familiar with.

**Example behaviors:**
- Voiced a concern about an existing bug that affects a large number of users
- Able to not panic during a user-facing support issue and identify the failing part of the stack, working with others to fix it

Communicates effectively with non-technical peers, able to present their work to the wider company.

Gives timely, helpful feedback to peers and managers.

Solicits feedback from others and is eager to find ways to improve.

**Example behaviors:**
- Delivered a Show and Tell presentation
- Acted as communicator during a support issue and updated appropriate stakeholders in a timely manner

Supports new team members, mentors peers in an ad-hoc way.

Able to mentor new team member.

**Example behaviors:**
- Acted as a mentor buddy for a new hire
- Helped a engineer understand how front-end works

Able to identify problems with the team and process, and investigate potential causes.

Communicates assumptions and gets clarification on tasks up front to minimize the need for rework.

Understands how their work fits in to the larger project and identifies problems with requirements.

Occasionally takes a lead in team processes.

**Example behaviors:**
- Facilitated a team retrospective
- Led a feature kick-off

Able to ask questions/seek clarity on what the product/sales team is doing and why.

**Example behaviors:**
- Raised a concern about the team's goals
- Asked the team PM for clarification on why a particular piece of work had been prioritised

roles.title: Engineer E3
roles.description: A Software Engineer E3 has a large amount of experience across multiple systems, and is able to estimate and reliably deliver complex tasks impacting multiple systems. They support and lead the technical direction in their team, and can communicate future plans and direction to technical and non-technical people.

skills.details:
Large amount of experience in multiple areas.

Understands and makes well-reasoned design decisions and trade-offs.

Able to identify tech areas that require ownership/improvement.

Demonstrates knowledge of industry trends.

Leaves things better than they found them.

**Example behaviors:**
- Investigated adding Jest to front-end, and shared results with the team
- Refactored a module in a service before adding functionality to it to make it more testable
- Took ownership of the support process

Able to deliver medium/large tasks that span multiple systems with support from peers.

Takes the initiative to fix issues before being assigned them.

Seeks empirical evidence through proof of concepts, tests and external research.

Able to effectively prioritise own workload and focus across many streams of work.

**Example behaviors:**
- Shipped a new microservice with support from colleagues
- Broke a large piece of work into smaller individual units that could be parallelised

Partners with sales and production and drives requirements that take into account all parties' needs.

Empathetic with the people who use the software they are producing and uses that empathy to guide decision-making.

Identifies problems/risks of own work and others.

**Example behaviors:**
- Suggested how we can improve a process in the aftermath of a issue instead of identifying whose fault it was
- Understood the context for a certain piece of technical debt instead of apportioning blame

Able to identify and communicate problems with technology and propose solutions/next steps.

Able to explain their work to the wider company, including to a nontechnical audience.

Practises active listening.

**Example behaviors:**
- Wrote a change note explaining the impact of a technical change
- Wrote a detailed and concise platform update email
- Listened to all points of view during a discussion without interrupting anyone

Able to deliver constructive, actionable feedback in an empathetic way.

**Example behaviors:**
- Suggested improvements empathetically during a code review
- Shared a blog post with a colleague to help them with a problem
- Identified when it would be more valuable for someone else to pick up a task (e.g. for educational purposes) instead of doing it themselves

Able to identify problems with the product team and process, investigate potential causes, and propose solutions/next steps.

Able to identify team and process areas that require ownership/improvement.

**Example behaviors:**
- Suggested a new way for team to collaborate
- Started and ran UI design meetup

Able to understand company goals, ask questions, challenge company goals.

Seek clarity on what the company is doing and why.

**Example behaviors:**
- Asked a question about next quarter's goals at a company meeting
- Understand company's goals in a 1:1 with manager
- Able to clearly explain company goals to others in the team

roles.title: Engineer E4
roles.description: A Software Engineer E4 has a large amount of experience across multiple systems, and is able to estimate and reliably deliver complex tasks impacting multiple systems. They actively coach and mentor engineers in their team, and are able to identify and resolve issues with technology and product processes.

skills.details:
Go-to expert in one area of the codebase.

Keeps up with industry best practices.

Enables other engineers to work more effectively.

Understands the broad architecture of the entire system.

Provides technical advice and weighs in on technical decisions that impact other teams or the company at large.

Researches and proposes new technologies.

**Example behaviors:**
- Made a plan to add Jest to stack, got feedback from principals/architects, worked with the team to roll-out
- Shared results migrating to Webpack

Scopes and stages work into well- defined milestones to avoid a monolithic deliverable.

Regularly delivers software on-time and is constantly working to make accurate estimates and deliver on those estimates.

Able to estimate delivery, proactively inform the team when delays likely, and suggest sensible workarounds/next steps to mitigate impact.

Owns the technical testing and performance plan for their projects.

**Example behaviors:**
- Reduced the scope of a feature in order to cut down development time
- Planned and executed a database migration that required downtime, informed the right people about it and sought the right support

Takes initiative to identify and solve important problems, coordinating with others on cross-cutting technical issues.

Sets direction at the project/service level and consistently influences decision- making at the business area/value level.

Idenitifies and proactively tackles technical debt before it grows into debt that requires significant up-front work to resolve.

**Example behaviors:**
- Identified time stamp error and assessed impact, fixed issue, tested and planned rolled-out with support team

Makes others better through code reviews, thorough documentation, technical guidance, and mentoring, or serving as a Tech Lead on a project.

Identifies and proposes strategies around technical problems affecting their team, communicates standards and gets buy-in on solutions.

Can explain the impact of their team's work to non-technical stakeholders.

**Example behaviors:**
- Delivered a presentation about a technical migration at a company meeting
- Wrote a technical article on the software group blog

Actively coach/mentor junior members of the team.

Actively works to share information with the team, e.g. best practices, technical approaches (avoiding silos).

**Example behaviors:**
- Prepared and delivered a presentation on Git best practices
- Introduced a short presentation on JavaScript best practices as part of onboarding

Participates in Architectural Review and provides feedback on projects outside of their core area.

Understands the tradeoffs between technical, analytical and product needs and leads to solutions that take all of these needs into account.

Able to identify problems with the product team and process, investigate potential causes, implement solutions/next steps, and proactively inform the right people of the change.

**Example behaviors:**
- Implemented a new bug-tracking process

Able to communicate/explain and advocate team's goals to engineers in the team.

**Example behaviors:**
- Clarified to a engineer on the team why a particular piece of work was valuable
- Encouraged engineers on the team to think about their work in terms of impact on the teams goals

roles.title: Leader L1
roles.description: A Leader L1 represents the technology aspect of a product team, leading the technical direction, guiding engineers, and communicating team progress alongside the Product Manager. Leader L1s have a large amount of technical experience working across multiple systems as well as great communication skills. They help keep the team focused and delivering value.

skills.details:
Keeps up with industry best practices.

Understands the impact of technology choices on the team.

Able to identify problems with and improvements to technology and tools.

Encourages engineers to own investigations and proposals for fixes and improvements.

**Example behaviors:**
- Researched and chose a technology for the new product feature

Scales themselves by delegating effectively.

Ensures tasks are completed as specified without micromanaging.

Able to estimate delivery of work across the product team, proactively informing the stakeholders on progress.

Effectively manages deliverables for the team, ensuring the prioritised work is planned and valuable/aligned with our goals.

Actively works to remove distractions and low impact work from the software team.

**Example behaviors:**
- Delegated a task in order to focus on unblocking the engineers

Focused on and responsible for the team's productivity and collective impact.

Able to read the morale of their product team and respond to their needs.

Works to actively improve morale in the product teams.

**Example behaviors:**
- Diffused tension between two participants in a retrospective
- Got the team excited about a potentially boring piece of work

Can explain the impact of their product team's work to non-technical stakeholders.

Can explain the team's goals to their team in an engaging way.

**Example behaviors:**
- Delivered a presentation about a technical migration at a company meeting

Actively mentors engineers, identifying areas for focus and improvement.

Contributes to the career development of others.

Coaches engineers to answers for their questions/problems.

**Example behaviors:**
- Did a workshop on how web application service works
- Worked with a engineer to organise a programming session to remove an information silo

Makes independent decisions for the team.

When the tech lead is acting as the reporting manager to others, the tech lead is expected to meet regularly with their direct reports, provide frequent feedback on their work, help the individuals set goals and work with the engineering lead or director to ensure employee growth and retention goals.

Able to identify problems with the product team and process, and encourage engineers to own investigations and proposals for fixes.

Able to support and lead technical direction in a team.

**Example behaviors:**
- Ran a project kick-off meeting

Understand and communicate the goals across product teams, and how they contribute to the company's success.

Works to make sure engineers understand the team and company's goals.

Help shape product team goals to ensure they're delivering value for the business.

**Example behaviors:**
- Worked with PM to pick a feasible metric for the quarter
- Had a 1:1 with a engineer and gave them the context behind the quarterly goal

roles.title: Engineer E5
roles.description: A Software Engineer E5 is an expert in a particular domain, such as a product or technology. Their role is to support and lead the technical direction across teams, share learnings, and effectively communicate future plans to product teams and the wider company. Software Engineers E5 proactively work with the team to identify areas for technical improvements and action them.

skills.details:
Expert in a domain and understands the impact of technology choices on the company.

Sought out for technical guidance.

Anticipates technical issues at the product level and makes architectural and design decisions to avoid them.

Owner of and expert on large sections of our codebase.

A record of creating sweeping improvements in stability, performance, and scalability across major business-critical systems.

**Example behaviors:**
- Planned and executed timestamp encoding and database migration

Recognized as a prolific contributor to core and side projects.

Consistently able to reduce the complexity of projects, services, and processes in order to get more done with less work.

Identifies areas where major work needs to be done in order to support teams current or future goals.

Able to estimate, plan and deliver large projects using a small team.

**Example behaviors:**
- Researched and made a plan to move to a new data warehousing platform
- Identified the weaknesses of the existing monitoring system, researched a better one, and worked with the teams migrate

Shapes broad architecture.

Ships multiple large services, complex libraries or major pieces of infrastructure.

Has made an obvious positive impact on the entire company's technical trajectory.

Detects and responds to the needs of teams and reports.

Listens and guides debates to help reach a consensus. Once a decision is made, clearly communicates and backs that decision.

Proactively communicate future plans and direction to technical and nontechnical people across teams.

Work with product teams to help them understand how our software architecture supports the team's business goals.

**Example behaviors:**
- Created a detailed document outlining a change that we needed to make to our architecture, and delivered presentations to the software team and wider team to explain the business need

Mentors groups of peers.

Coaches senior engineers and technical leads in the team.

Works on high leverage activities.

Multiplies the effectiveness of others by facilitating cross-team work.

Sets short to medium-term strategic technical direction, able to look ahead 6- 12 months and identify the areas of greatest need and create plans to improve them.

Able to identify problems with the product team and process, investigate potential causes, work with the team to propose solutions/next steps, and make sure the fixes are prioritised and completed.

Understands the goals across product teams, and how they contribute to the company's success.

Help shape product team goals to ensure they're delivering value for the business, considering our technical strategy.

roles.title: Engineer E6
roles.description: A Software Engineer E6 is responsible for leading the Software Engineer E6 group. They ensure the Software Engineers E6 are working effectively, by providing coaching, mentoring, and guidance where required. They organise the group in order to deliver value for the software teams and business.

skills.details:
Setting technical direction.

Anticipates broad technical change and ensures Syft is always ahead of the curve.

Able to recognize and make trade-offs with respect to the whole system.

Understands deeply the entire architecure for a major part of our business and is able to articulate clearly the scaling and reliability limits of that area.

Expert across multiple domains.

Able to identify problems with technology, and encourage the Architects to own investigations and proposals for fixes.

**Example behaviors:**
- Moved company tech stack to new infrastructure
- Planned and executed moving to distributed architecture

Consistently delivers large systems involving contribution from one or more teams on time at a high level of quality.

Quickly breaks down complex problems into possible solutions (options), knowns, and unknowns, in order to get to solid resolutions faster.

Capable of debugging the most complex problems that the team encounters.

Able to estimate, plan and deliver large projects using multiple teams.

Identifies technology strategic growth opportunities that enable Syft to grow as a business.

Plays a key role in developing multi-year technology strategy for complete and critical areas of the business that encompass multiple systems and teams.

Decisions have a direct impact on the long-term success or failure of Syft.

Creates architecture that enables many potential futures without knowing exactly what the future is.

Detects and responds to the needs of product teams, reports, and Architects group.

Communicates multi-year technical strategy and leads the team in identifying future strategic areas for development.

Leads the conversations internally about the direction of major areas of the technology, drives wide-team consensus to the adoption of this direction, and uses this direction to inspire engineers.

Communicates the awesomeness of the Syft tech community externally.

IdentifiesareasthatSyftcanshare effectively with the outside world and guides the creation of content and communication around these areas.

Represent and communicate the role of the Architects, goals and priorities, deliverables, to the business.
Coaches across the business.

Seen as a role model and mentor to every technical member of the team.

Primarily acts as a multiplier through high leverage activities such as by building systems, authoring tools, or introducing standards, policies, and patterns that raise the level of productivity of the entire organization.

Able to identify problems with the product team and process, and encourage the Architects to own investigations and proposals for fixes.
Work with the Architects to ensure a technical strategy exists, and has been considered as part of the planning process.

roles.title: Leader L2
roles.description: A Leader L2 works with a number of teams, supporting their engineers and processes. They are responsible for managing and leading engineers across the technology team, guiding and supporting their growth. They ensure we have the right technical skills in the team to tackle the challenges the business is solving.

skills.details:
Understands and practices lean/agile software development and management.

Produces quality metrics on the SDLC process.

Aware of the impact tools and technology have on development team productivity and happiness.

Management skills (mentoring, coaching,development, admin, planning, etc). Understand the technical challenges of the product teams.

**Example behaviors:**
- Has weekly 1:1s with reports

Proactive in identifying and clearing roadblocks for the team.

Creates progression plans to develop careers of the technology team.

Ensure the technology team has the right expertise, working with the ED/CTO to inform the hiring plan.

Responsible for the technical hiring process.

Evangelises the work of the technology team, internally to other areas, and externally.

**Example behaviors:**
- Advertise open tech roles, review CVs, interview candidates, and run debrief sessions
- Ensure the team publishes a update about our latest software team initiative/achievement

Excels at getting the team to focus on the highest-impact projects.

Able to lead recruiting efforts and determine headcount for their team.

Partners effectively with product to manage scope and delierables for the technical side of the product roadmap.

Detects and responds to the needs of teams and reports.

Ensures the team has a good work-life balance, and is taking enough vacation.

**Example behaviors:**
- Turned a problematic situation into an opportunity to learn and improve
- Identified tension between two team members and took proactive steps to remove it

Communicates context to the team and surfaces requirements to upper management.

Develops and improves communication channels between product teams.

Communicates timeline, scope and technical concerns to relevant teams.

Acts as a conduit between technology and other areas of the business, shielding and fielding questions where necessary.

**Example behaviors:**
- Organised and ran a weekly Technology Leadership meeting

Develops new coaches and mentors in the team.

Coaches direct reports, identifies areas for their progression.

Guide engineers across teams, supporting development of their technical and product skills.

Help grow reports and highlight areas for progression.

**Example behaviors:**
- Identified an opportunity for a team member to be mentored by another team member and worked with them to make it happen
- Coached a engineer to prepare and deliver a dev talk

Manages independently.

Sets clear expectations for team members.

Support processes across several product teams.

Manage and grow the technology team.

Able to identify areas of strategic technical debt and provide cost/benefit analysis for eliminating this debt and suggested timelines for how to prioritize it.

Leads delivery of major initiatives on clear timelines.

**Example behaviors:**
- Identified an information silo and worked with the teams to mitigate it
- Found an internal talent development programme to help direct report grow

Able to question and contribute to company goals.

Understand and help to drive how product teams and reports deliver business value.

roles.title: Leader L3
roles.description: A Leader L3 works across the technology team, managing and leading leaders and developing future leaders in the team. The Leader L3 identifies areas of focus for the technology team and their processes. They represent the software team to the rest of the organisation, and help shape the team's strategy.

skills.details:
Ensures their organization has appropriately high technical competence and strives for excellence.

Researches new technologies to stay abreast of industry trends and standards.

Contributes to architecture by asking the right questions to ensure architecture matches business needs for the area.

Capable of jumping in to help debug and triage critical systems as needed.

Management skills (mentoring, coaching, development, admin, planning, etc). Understand the technical challenges of the technology team.

Develops and deploys new strategies for building a high velocity, high performance development organization in line with our emerging customer needs.

Supports technical innovation and leads the creation, continual refinement, and active enforcement of our development standards so that our technology can be leveraged as a sustainable competitive advantage.

Participates in staff recruitment, performance assessments, training, and career development.

Responsible for headcount planning and personnel evolution for multiple engineering areas.

As necessary, the director manages vendor and external relationships, and participates in the budgeting process.

Provides leadership to software development managers, addresses technical, resource and personnel issues.

Builds and supports high functioning, motivated teams.

Creates an organization that understands how to balance technical debt vs business goals.

Proactively improves the morale of the engineering team.

**Example behaviors:**
- Organised a celebration of completion of a large piece of work

Collaborates across functional areas to define,prioritize and ensure implementation of specific innovations to improve technical functionality in support of business needs, efficiencies and revenue.

Able to communicate technical concepts to business stakeholders as well as communicate business objectives to the technical team.

Develops and improves communication channels for the whole software team.

Promotes Syft externally.

Owns the performance setting and review process for teams under their oversight.

**Example behaviors:**
- Gave a presentation about Syft at jobs fair

Proactively nurtures the talent of the senior staff in their areas.

Creates ways for people to mentor each other.

Guide engineers across the technology team to solutions, supporting development of their technical and product skills.

Help grow reports and highlight areas for progression.

**Example behaviors:**
- Delivered a coaching workshop
- Introduced brownbag talks and lined up speakers

Ability to identify and work with the team to fix problems with software team processes.

Support processes across several product teams.

Manage, grow, and help lead the technology team.

**Example behaviors:**
- Develop a quarterly peer review process

Understands and affects the role of the software team within Syft.

Understand how the technology team and other functional teams deliver business value, and use knowledge to help shape strategy of technology team.

**Example behaviors:**
- Influenced the company strategy by voicing the needs of the engineering team during planning
- Built a productive relationship between the technology team and the international teams
